com.ngeen.asset

Class Asset<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ngeen.asset.Asset<T>

  • public class Asset<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    The base class for assets. It is a generic class. You usualy get an asset of a type from the asset factory located in your class extending Ngeen. You have references to it in pretty much every class you work in(Script, etc.) The types Asset can use are written in AssetFactory. To get the data, use getData.
    Author:
    Dragos

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods

      Get the data held by the asset(Texture, Sound, etc.)
      java.lang.String getFolder()
      Get the folder holding this object, relative to your data folder, that is in your project classpath.

      Get the id of the object.

        private int _ResId

    • Method Detail

      • getData

        public final T getData()
        Get the data held by the asset(Texture, Sound, etc.)
        Returns:
        The data held by this asset.

      • dispose

        public void dispose()
        If you call this, and i don't suggest it, you will no longer have one asset. The best way to do this is to load/unload folders, so it is harder to make mistakes.

      • getId

        public final int getId()
        Get the id of the object.

      • getPath

        public final java.lang.String getPath()
        Get the object path without the folder it is in. That is, the path relative to the folder _Folder path. Get the folder path with getFolder
        Returns:
        The path to this asset relative to it's holding folder.

      • getFolder

        public java.lang.String getFolder()
        Get the folder holding this object, relative to your data folder, that is in your project classpath.
        Returns:
        Folder path.
